description: Trigger test cases for the task-runner skill (v2.0.0 — two-mode design). Positive cases should activate the skill in the indicated mode; negative cases should NOT activate the skill.

modes.INTAKE: Triggered by user message containing task intent
modes.DISPATCHER: Triggered by heartbeat poll or cron systemEvent

positive.input: Add these tasks for me: 1. Look up the weather in Paris 2. Create a summary file
positive.reason: Explicit 'add these tasks' phrase with numbered list

positive.input: Do this for me: search for the latest AI news and summarize it in a markdown file
positive.reason: Explicit 'do this for me' trigger phrase

positive.input:
My task list for today:
- Research competitor pricing
- Write a pricing comparison report
- Send the report to #research channel
positive.reason: Contains 'task list' phrase with bulleted multi-item list
'My tasks' trigger phrase — status check in INTAKE mode
'Task status' trigger phrase — user wants current queue state
Task control command — skip T-NN pattern
Task control command — retry T-NN resets task to pending
Task control command — cancel T-NN marks as skipped

negative.reason: Single scheduling request — handled by scheduling skill directly
Single web search — answer directly without task overhead
Trivial single lookup — no task infrastructure needed
Single info lookup — answer directly, too trivial for task queue

negative.input: How do I use the message tool?

notes: All 17 positive cases should activate the skill in the indicated mode
All 7 negative cases should NOT activate the skill
INTAKE mode: prefer activating when user intent is to add/manage tasks
DISPATCHER mode: only activated by systemEvents, never by direct user messages
Task control commands (skip/retry/cancel T-NN) always trigger INTAKE
Status checks ('show tasks', 'task status') always trigger INTAKE
When ambiguous between INTAKE and answering directly: if message has ≥2 distinct action items, activate INTAKE
